title: State Court Prohibits Use of North Carolina Congressional Map for 2020 Elections
text:
A panel of North Carolina judges on Monday blocked the state from using a Republican-drawn congressional map for the 2020 elections, stepping in after the U.S. Supreme Court declined to referee the matter.

A three-judge panel in Wake County Superior Court said the district lines, drawn by the GOP in 2016 to produce a 10-3 Republican advantage in North Carolina’s congressional delegation, appeared to be an unlawful partisan gerrymander.

The ruling wasn’t a final decision on the merits, but the court said a group of voters challenging the map “have shown a likelihood of succeeding on the merits of their claims that these districts violate multiple fundamental rights guaranteed by the North Carolina Constitution.”

The panel issued a preliminary injunction that prohibits use of the map.

The ruling is the latest shoe to drop for North Carolina Republicans who control the state legislature and used their majority to draw voting maps that were intended to provide them with enduring political success.

The same state court last month ruled that Republicans improperly gerrymandered districts for state legislative seats to ensure the GOP would maintain power. The court in that case ordered the legislature to draw new district lines, which it did a couple of weeks later.

The rulings come after the U.S. Supreme Court in June ruled that federal judges have no authority to place limits on the drawing of voting maps for partisan gain. That decision, written by Chief Justice John Roberts, left open the prospect that state courts could rule on partisan gerrymandering claims under their own state constitutions. Voting-rights advocates are turning to state courts in the wake of that ruling.

The North Carolina court in both of its rulings has relied in part on a provision of the North Carolina Constitution that guarantees free and fair elections.

Some 30 states have a constitutional requirement for free elections.

Write to Brent Kendall at brent.kendall@wsj.com
